review_title: Not the worst but certainly not the best.
pros: The majority of the line managers in my department are lovely to work with and try their best to fight for what is in the best interest of their teams. Not expected to work Bank holidays, overtime opportunities, increased annual leave over time, very supportive of carers, give more than basic pay for maternity leave which also increases after being here for over a year. They pay someone to provide wellbeing sessions to talk through the emotions of the calls, and sometimes give the whole team half days off for wellbeing so we can recharge.
cons: Starting to feel like a call centre with increased pressure to meet targets with no incentive. Little -no opportunities to advance unless you move to entirely different department, they say they match salary to the average of others in the charity sector but I have to see evidence of this, constantly taking responsibilities from other departments and putting them on the team I work for without much warning - even when they ask for our input on this they will hear the whole team say 'no, its too much' and still do it anyway. High turn over of staff and the general team is expected to train new staff constantly as well as meet targets etc. Little actual training on how to handle calls when you first start, not allowed to work from home on a permeant basis, very corporate run, not very forgiving of mental health conditions. Systems are confusing and when we bring ideas forward for positive change they are ignored (not by our line managers, they are great!). I have worked in much work places, they are not villains by any means and I genuinely feel they want to help those with dementia but do not feel they want to help their staff or listen to us.

pros: There are so many pro's. The main one is: that I've never worked anywhere that is truly committed to making genuine improvements. There's a great culture: supportive, constructive, and inspiring. And a determination to always improve and keep moving forward - putting people with dementia at the heart of what we do, and genuine care for employees and volunteers who deliver this work.

review_title: The best place I have ever worked!
pros: Alzheimer’s Society is the best place that I have ever worked, I love my new role and wished I had joined sooner. I have developed my skills so much in my first 8 months working here. There is a genuine positive culture that celebrates people’s achievements and successes. They put well-being as a priority, giving staff well-being days and have a recognition scheme. The communication is fantastic, with weekly staff briefings, ‘Ask us Anything’ sessions with the Executive Leadership Team, as well as lunch and learn sessions and a weekly newsletter. You get to hear from different teams around the organisation and people affected by dementia to and find out what they are working on and hear their experiences. I feel valued and supported and I couldn’t be happier :)

job_title: Volunteer Development Officer in Pontypool, Wales
pros:
My experience of two years working for the Alzheimer’s Society is a curate’s egg – good in parts at best. The pluses - there are some really fantastic people working for it, passionate, knowledgeable and committed to improving the lives of people affected by dementia. There’s plenty of learning on offer. It is humbling to work in an environment where so many employees and volunteers have skin in the game as they have direct experience of dementia themselves. 
Since covid kicked in the charity has had a bumpy ride. Lots of offices have closed and staff numbers significantly reduced. It has a new CEO: Kate Lee, who is bright, charming, a clear and strategic thinker, down to earth, both funny and charismatic. She has moved mountains to make the society more transparent and focused on what it is there for. The distance between senior management and the front line has been slashed. You can ask the CEO questions and get honest answers which really counts.
cons: Sadly this change has passed by the Volunteer Development part of the Society which has a festering culture of favourites and individuals who seemingly can walk on water. Its characteristics include bullying, a fascination for process over outcomes and soul sapping levels of micromanagement. If the people who head it up ever had emotional intelligence, genuine talent or insight it’s skilfully hidden. This part of the charity only works in top down mode. It repeatedly ignores what talent it has and is threatened by - if not completely deaf to - constructive feedback. Whilst pay isn’t a prime motivator for many of us in the sector, salaries here are, at best, mediocre to poor.

pros: Great CEO, wonderful people and cause.

pros: Like many large charitable organisations these days, the front line staff are mostly dedicated and hardworking, going above and beyond to make a difference to the clients and carers.
cons: Also like many large charitable organisations, the management culture as of early 2020 seemed very much focused on branding, sometimes at the expense of best practice. In a culture of cutbacks, this has meant overloading of staff and lower management, and top-down grand ideas (eg Side by Side) that don't seem to have much basis in the real world. Managers who impose these ideas then leave, and remaining staff have to deal with the consequences for services.
